results.title: Nigel & Frank meet their matchbox
results.creator_credit: Sam Howie and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
A light-hearted animated story of friendship and just how far two old mates will let greed and envy come between them when they discover a magic matchbox. No dialogue.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Howie and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT

results.title: The Urban migration
results.creator_credit: James Paul and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
This rather grim story in black and white of urbanisation versus nature uses cut-out and hand-drawn animation. No dialogue.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.

results.title: Tree of us
results.creator_credit: Vilakone Phachanthavong and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
Vilakone has created powerful graphics in this animated work about the family of the future through the use of a predominantly red background, with black and white hand-drawn images. No dialogue.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.

results.title: Under the influence
results.creator_credit: Fletcher Cheng and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
One wrong decision and your life can turn into hell. An intriguing computer animated moral tale of alcohol and addiction with a great soundtrack - music by Fletcher Cheng. No dialogue.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2004.

results.title: WCSC
results.brief_description:
Tune in as Jerry and Bruce commentate the sports event of the millennium! Rushkov versus Javichenko. Be sure to experience the giddying highs of Friday night WCSC live at Viagro Stadium.
Animated work. Includes animated nudity. Voices - Trent Baker, Simon Philamon. Written, directed and animated by Michael Hill.

results.title: Uncle
results.creator_credit: VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne and Adam Elliot
results.brief_description: An award-winning short about a favoured Uncle who was a thoroughly ordinary and a thoroughly decent man. Peppered with wryly comic remembrances of a seventies childhood, ‘Uncle’ is a moving tribute to suburban eccentricity and familial loyalty.
results.creator_credit_for_label: VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne and Adam Elliot

results.title: Small treasures
results.brief_description: Based on autobiographical experience, Small Treasures is about the still birth of a child. Written in a diary form, it follows an ordinary pregnancy through to its devastating conclusion. Beautifully made and hand coloured this film won best short at the Venice Film Festival.
results.description: Based on autobiographical experience, Small Treasures is about the still birth of a child. Written in a diary form, it follows an ordinary pregnancy through to its devastating conclusion. Beautifully made and hand coloured this film won best short at the Venice Film Festival.

results.title: Ashputtle: or the mother's ghost
results.brief_description: A mother does what has to be done to help her daughter - even if it means returning from the grave. A retelling of a traditional folktale (Grimm’s ‘Ashputtle’ as reworked by Angela Carter). Ashputtle is an unloved, uncared for and barely human child until her dead mother rises from the grave to look after her. It is a beautifully cut-out animation that explores themes of identity, responsibility, disintegration and transformation, in a bold and vibrant visual style.
results.description: A mother does what has to be done to help her daughter - even if it means returning from the grave. A retelling of a traditional folktale (Grimm’s ‘Ashputtle’ as reworked by Angela Carter). Ashputtle is an unloved, uncared for and barely human child until her dead mother rises from the grave to look after her. It is a beautifully cut-out animation that explores themes of identity, responsibility, disintegration and transformation, in a bold and vibrant visual style.

A retelling of a traditional folktale (Grimm’s ‘Ashputtle’ as reworked by Angela Carter). It is a beautifully cut-out animation that explores themes of identity, responsibility, disintegration and transformation, in a bold and vibrant visual style.
